name: A story about grit
author: Michel Moreau
post:
One of the greatest thing in life is the feeling of succeeding at something after having struggled miserably for a significant period of time.

I have a close friend, Leo.

Leo chose to quit his 6 figure engineering job to start a company around the age of 24. He went on to live 5 years with friends but didn’t really have a bedroom (for Canadian standards) - it was more like a closet with a single bed in it. He convinced our friends to rent the closet for 200$/month. His roommates were not entrepreneurs and were smarts in their own ways. They were all progressing rapidly in their careers, while Leo was struggling to find product-market fit with his idea for years.

However, Leo was regularly stating he was making progress over these years, yet most people of his surroundings started questioning his plans right after year 1. People tried to convince him to get back to an engineering job many times, tried to talk him into the fact he was becoming a bit crazy, were laughing at him and thinking he was a joke, etc. Leo chose to keep at it regardless.

Leo took a part-time job around year 3 to be able to continue on his entrepreneurial journey. Finally, he started earning money from his business during year four and signed a huge deal during year five which instantly made him the biggest earner of anyone in his group of friends. Even more beautiful, a lot of our friends, including myself, were starting to use his service!

Leo was not a joke anymore.

For anything that’s hard, you never **really** know when you’re gonna get there. Trust yourself and the process.

name: On people with a high IQ
author: Michel Moreau
post:
They have capacity for intelligence that potentially never translates to intelligence itself.

Bill Gates, Larry Page, Einstein, Newton, Elon Musk, Nikola Tesla, and many other high IQs applied their capacity for intelligence and made something impactful out of it.

A 180-IQ guy whose only hobby is to get better at IQ testing potentially has capacity for intelligence but is not intelligent until he applies this capacity to something meaningful/impactful.

name: Lacking personality
author: Michel Moreau
post:
Lacking personality can mean a lot of things.

However, in my humble opinion, a common usage of the term lack of personality that hinders one’s own well-being over the long term relates to personality repression.

Personality repression means excessively complying and living one’s life through the influence of other people’s desires/opinions, ignoring one’s own. Not having a sense of self-expression and self-directedness for one’s own life, always referring to what other people are doing to figure out what to do next for oneself.

As a real-life example of that, you can imagine someone who radically changes her day-to-day behaviors every time she changes her life partner, whether it be a boyfriend, girlfriend, etc.

Other real-life potential cues of personality repression:

  • A ridiculously high frequency of “me too” or similar statements in someone’s conversation stance with another person.
  • Drastic personality modification depending on the group a person spends time with. It can be in the way someone dresses, talks, thinks, eats, exercises, or any other manifestation of personality.
  • A recurrent feeling of unease after saying yes to someone, when you really wanted to say no (or vice versa).

Jeffrey Young talks about this concept in his book Reinventing Your Life, in which he discusses different lifetraps people can fall into that are usually developed through emotionally-charged past life experiences. The one that relates to personality repression in his book is called the subjugation lifetrap, as in subjugating to other people’s needs and wants.

I highly recommend his book if the concept of personality repression resonated with you, even if to a mild extent.

Take good care.

name: The Career You Should Pursue
author: Michel Moreau
post:
If you google this question online, you will find this question has been answered multiple times.

I would bet many people provide specific answers based on personality, skills, temperament. And this is fine – being conscious of your human nature is a good thing, and hopefully it will guide you toward a career you will enjoy.

However, nobody will nor can choose for you in the end. Here is an approach that will lead you to choose a career that adds meaning to your life:

  • Learn broadly and constantly on many topics. Psychology, philosophy, politics, engineering, mathematics, physics, arts, history, etc. It will help you form a broad view of the world you live in.
  • Find the problems that are important to you and the people around you. As your view of the world expands, do not hesitate to change course along the way.
  • Determine the skills needed to fix the problems you want to solve and acquire them. Persevere.
  • Connect with people interested in solving the same problems you want to solve.
  • With courage, patience, and self-directedness, be willing to try and fix the identified problems. Again, try to surround yourself with critical but empowering influences wanting you to succeed.

Self-directedness toward fixing the problems that matter to you, with the right people besides you, is your only path to having a meaningful career.

Don't waste too much time listening to other people's opinions. In the matter of career choices, do your own thinking and experiencing.

name: On Being Rigid
author: Michel Moreau
post:
The personality traits that are usually harmful are the ones that are too rigid.

By rigid, I mean traits you display in multiple scenarios as an unconscious defense mechanism, that usually result in lasting and repeating negative consequences for yourself or your relationships.

Jeffrey E. Young, a clinical psychologist, professor at Columbia University, and inventor of Schema Therapy and the term lifetraps, wrote extensively about these rigid traits, namely in his book Reinventing Your Life, in which he describes the origin of these type of traits, the way they manifest, and how to have better control over these manifestations.

If you want to better understand your human nurture, how your past influences your present personality, digging into Jeffrey E. Young’s writings is a very good starting point.

Fairwell.

name: ten guidelines for maintainable code from Joost Visser et alia
author: Michel Moreau
post:
Write short units of code.

Write simple units of code.

Write code once.

Keep unit interfaces small.

Seperate concerns in module.

Couple components architecture loosely.

Keep component architecture balanced.

Keep your codebase small.

Automate tests.

Write clean code.

These rules were taken from the excellent book Building Maintainable Software: Ten Guidelines for Future-Proof Code

name: On life pivoting
author: Michel Moreau
post:
You want to switch career, start a business or get a promotion.

You want to lose weight, sleep longer, stop smoking or gain muscles.

You want to breakup, find a life partner, meet more girls or like-minded guys.

You want to buy a nice house, a dream car, a shiny watch or head-turning outfits.

You want to be less materialistic, live simply or be contempt with what you have.

You want to feel happier, complete, successful or more connected to meaningful others.

You want to be sociable, emotionally intelligent, less needy or more balanced.

You want to be able to have difficult conversations, display honesty toward yourself and others in all situations.

You want. Wanting invites either stagnation or unhabitual change.

Stagnation implies pain.

Unhabitual change implies pain.

Stagnation implies an unconscious, visceral, long-lasting, deferred, potentially explosive pain leading to the absolute certainty of an unfulfilled want.

Unhabitual change implies a conscious, acute, ephemeral, likely mind-expanding pain leading to the potential fulfillment of your want.

Being conscious of these two types of pains and their outcomes makes the choice between stagnation and unhabitual change obvious.

Through courage to endure pain of unhabitual change, living your best life becomes more likely.
